awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: New Avenues to Cosmic Acceleration
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will consist of a theoretical investigation into the nature of dark energy - the agent that causes the accelerated expansion of the universe.  This will be accomplished through the twin tools of fundamental particle-physics theory, along with cosmological observations, which include galaxy clustering, the hot and cold spots in the microwave background, and the bending of light by galaxies (gravitational lensing), to improve our knowledge of the mechanism responsible for the current period of acceleration. The project will focus on providing a further stress test of the data to search for any evidence of alternative theoretical explanations for the cosmic acceleration, including modifications of the General Theory of Relativity. Important to the success of this program is an outreach component, which will be coordinated with the SUPA program at Syracuse University. The outreach will include communicating our results to local high school students and more broadly to improving the science curriculum throughout the state of NY and beyond.

The quality of data from cosmological probes of Dark Energy (DE) continues to grow at an impressive rate, whereas theoretical progress in our understanding of the underlying mechanism behind cosmic acceleration has been far more modest. As the accuracy of cosmological measurements continues to improve it is crucial to establish an economic and systematic way in which to use data to guide theoretical efforts to reveal the nature of DE.  The Effective Field Theory (EFT) of DE provides such an approach. By focusing on the fundamental symmetries of different DE models, rather than the details of a particular model realization, the EFT groups DE models into universal classes based on their general properties. This approach is analogous to the use of EFT methods in particle physics and condensed matter, where it has been very successful in connecting theory and experiment.   This project will focus on developing the EFT of DE to establish whether the EFT framework is robust enough to provide a uniform approach to the study of DE.  On the practical side, the investigators will work to establish a parameterization of the EFT that is best suited for bridging the gap between fundamental theory and cosmological observations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to investigate the possible interpretations of data that indicate that the expansion of the universe is speeding up. 

To give more context, consider that the discovery of the acceleration of the universe, made about 20 years ago and awarded with the Physics Nobel Prize in 2011, has led to a major mystery in the field of cosmology - that  of the physical mechanism behind cosmic acceleration. The cause of the acceleration is generically called dark energy, but its physical origin is not yet understood. Dark energy is phenomenologically described with its pressure-to density ratio - the equation of state - which can potentially vary with time. At the same time, it is possible that modifications to Einstein's gravity make it *appear* that the universe is accelerating. These modified-gravity scenarios, much investigated by cosmologists worldwide, are typically constrained separately from (or, in parallel to) standard dark-energy analyses that assume unmodified, Einstein gravity and a new dark-energy fluid.


In our project, we have asked the following questions: what if modified gravity is at work, but data are analyzed with the standard (unmodified-gravity) assumptions? The cosmological parameters would be biased, but in which direction? And, given that modified-gravity analyses of general classes of such models are rarely if ever attempted because of the complexity of such an analysis, can the relative shifts in the (standard) cosmological parameters actually tell us that modified gravity is at work?

For the first time to our knowledge, we were able to answer all of the above questions quantitatively. We set up an analysis pipeline where we combed through thousands of modified-gravity from a very general class of such models- the so-called Horndeski models. For each Horndeski model, we computed the theoretically predicted cosmological quantities, such as the cosmic microwave background power spectrum. We then generated synthetic data from each model, and analyzed it by assuming, crucially, the dark-energy (unmodified-gravity) model. And finally, for each Horndeski model we were able to assess the shifts in the standard cosmological parameters relative to their true values.

We found that even very general modified-gravity scenarios lead to very specific, largely one-dimensional, shifts (relative to true values) in the space of standard parameters. Specifically, we found that the best-fit values of the inferred parameters describing the equation of state of dark energy carve out a one-dimensional dimension in their parameter space.  Therefore, if the real data, when analyzed in the standard dark-energy model, end up favoring this mutual relation between dark-energy parameters that we found, then we will have a hint that modified gravity is at work. In such a realistic situation, we can then follow up the standard, dark-energy  analysis with a suitably chosen modified-gravity one.

We have also studied the impact of modified gravity, still under the general Horndeski class of models, for the currently much discussed tension in the amplitude of mass fluctuations, sigma_8. This parameter is currently favored to be higher as measured by the cosmic microwave background data than than from probes of cosmic structure. We found that analyzing the modified-gravity data under the (erroneous) assumption of dark energy almost always suppresses the inferred value of sigma_8 relative to the truth. Because our analysis assumes the cosmic microwave background data which in reality prefer a *high*sigma_8, we find that modified-gravity scenarios only exacerbate the sigma_8 tension.


Our work opens the door to further quantitative comparisons of the modified-gravity and standard dark-energy cosmological-data analyses. These will become all the more important as data from upcoming surveys (DESI, LSST, HSC, HETDEX, Euclid, and Roman observatories) start coming in.
